case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. the assessee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1394 of 1970 filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1969 of the High Court at Madras in Tax Case No. 124 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1969 of the High Court at Madras in Tax Case No. 124 of 1965. C. Manchanda, P. L. Juneja and R. N. Sachthey, for the

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the referred question in the negative in favour of the assessee respondent.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of Madras High Court whereby that companyrt answered the following question referred to it under section 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred

facts.text: Referred question: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: the following question referred to it under section 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act  in the negative in favour of the assessee respondent Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B 2  ?

facts.text: Matter relates to assessment year 1961-62.

anchor.surface_text: ? The matter relates to assessment year 1961-62. The assessee is a public limited companypany carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of yarn.

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of yarn.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a public limited companypany carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of yarn. The assessee held shares in the following companypanies as under Indian Mills Supply Company  Private  Limited, 2,760 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/-

facts.text: Assessee held 2,760 shares of Rs. 100 each in Indian Mills Supply Company Private Limited.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee held shares in the following companypanies as under Indian Mills Supply Company  Private  Limited, 2,760 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/- Harveys  Private  Limited, 1,000 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/-

facts.text: Assessee held 1,000 shares of Rs. 100 each in Harveys Private Limited.

anchor.surface_text: Harveys  Private  Limited, 1,000 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/- Pendyan Weaving Mills  Private  Limited, 1,800 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/-.

facts.text: Assessee held 1,800 shares of Rs. 100 each in Pandyan Weaving Mills Private Limited.

anchor.surface_text: Pendyan Weaving Mills  Private  Limited, 1,800 shares of the face value of Rs. 100/-. The above three companypanies went into voluntary liquidation in December, 1959.

facts.text: The three companies went into voluntary liquidation in December 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The above three companypanies went into voluntary liquidation in December, 1959. In the companyrse of the liquidation proceedings, the liquidiators made distribution

facts.text: Liquidators distributed Rs. 4,57,858, Rs. 1,41,739 and Rs. 1,83,175 respectively to assessee in relevant year.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of the liquidation proceedings, the liquidiators made distribution in the relevant year of account and the assessee companypany got cash or assets in lieu of cash of the amount of Rs. 4,57,858, Rs. 1,41,739 and Rs. 1,83,175 in respect of Indian Mills Company  Private  Limited, Harveys  Private  Limited and Pandyan Weaving Mills  Private  Limited respectively.

facts.text: Revenue viewed capital gain of Rs. 96,735.85 from Indian Mills, Rs. 41,168.88 from Harveys, total Rs. 1,37,904.73 minus loss Rs. 41,960.56 from Pandyan = Rs. 95,944.

anchor.surface_text: The revenue took the view that by reason of the distribution of assets of the three private companypanies under liquidation by the liquidators, there had been a capital gain of Rs. 96,735.85 in respect of Indian Mills Supply Company  Private  Limited and Rs. 41,168-88 in respect of Harveys  Private  Limited making a total of Rs. 1,37,904.73. Out of that, loss amounting to Rs. 41,960.56

facts.text: Assessee first showed Rs. 95,944 as capital gains but later filed statement showing loss of Rs. 59,104 based on acquisition cost by distributing companies.

anchor.surface_text: Out of that, loss amounting to Rs. 41,960.56 in respect of Pandyan Weaving Mills  Private  Limited was deducted, leaving a balance of Rs. 95,944.00. The assessee companypany at first showed the sum of Rs. 95,944.00 as capital gains but subsequently it filed a statement showing a loss of Rs. 59,104 on the basis that the companyt of shares distributed by the liquidators should be taken at the figure at which they had been acquired by the companypanies which distributed the shares.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed assessee to capital gain of Rs. 95,944.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer assessed the assessee companypany to capital gain at the sum of Rs. 95,944. Aggrieved by the order of the Income-tax Officer the assessee filed appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the order of the Income-tax Officer the assessee filed appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and on being unsuccessful there, filed further appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and on being unsuccessful there, filed further appeal before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. The main companytention which was raised on behalf of the assessee was that the transaction in question involved numbersale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer

facts.text: Tribunal held assessee liable to tax on Rs. 95,944 under section 12B as there was exchange or transfer or relinquishment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that there was an exchange or transfer of shares and assets in question. The transaction, according to the Tribunal, companyld also be viewed as a relinquishment. The assessee was companysequently held liable to pay tax on the sum of Rs. 95,944 under section 12B of the Act.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court on application of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was companysequently held liable to pay tax on the sum of Rs. 95,944 under section 12B of the Act. The question reproduced above was thereafter, on the application of the assessee, referred to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held that liquidator's distribution in voluntary liquidation involves no sale, transfer, exchange or relinquishment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court while answering the question in the negative held that when a liquidator distributes the assets of a companypany which has gone into voluntary liquidation, he is performing a legal function and there is numberelement of sale, transfer, exchange or relinquishment involved in such distribution.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed against High Court judgment reported in 1969 74 T.T.R. 623.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court is reported in  1969  74 T.T.R. 623. Before dealing further, we may mention that capital gains were charged for the first time by the Income Tax and Excess Profit Tax  Amendment  Act, 1947

facts.text: Capital gains tax introduced by Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1947 (Act 22 of 1947), inserting section 12B, for gains after March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing further, we may mention that capital gains were charged for the first time by the Income Tax and Excess Profit Tax  Amendment  Act, 1947  Act 22 of 1947  which inserted section 12B in the Act. It taxed capital gains arising after March 31, 1946.

facts.text: Capital gains tax abolished by Indian Finance Act, 1949 for gains before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The tax on capital gains was virtually abolished by the Indian Finance Act, 1949 which companyfined the operation of that section to capital gains arising before April 1, 1948.

facts.text: Capital gains tax revived from April 1, 1957 by Finance (No. 3) Act of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Capital gains tax was, however, revived with effect from April 1, 1957 by the Finance  No. 3  Act of 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that distribution by liquidator does not amount to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer under section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that distribution of the assets of the companypanies in liquidation does number amount to a transaction of sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer so as to attract section 12B of the Act.

facts.text: Assessee not liable to tax on Rs. 95,944 as capital gains under section 12B.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we find it difficult to hold that the assessee companypany is liable to pay tax on capital gains as companytemplated by section 12B of the Act in respect of the amount of Rs. 95,944.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 95,944/- is liable to tax under Section 12B 2  ? The matter relates to assessment year 1961-62. The assessee is a public limited companypany carrying

issues.text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the distribution of assets of the companies which had gone into voluntary liquidation by the liquidators to the assessee company resulted in a transaction which amounted to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the distribution of assets of the companies which had gone into voluntary liquidation by the liquidators to the assessee company resulted in a transaction which amounted to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer. Mr. Manchanda on behalf of the appellant has argued in this Court that the transaction in question amounted to sale or transfer.

arguments.claim: The transaction in question involved no sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer and as such, the amount in question was not capital gain under section 12B of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention which was raised on behalf of the assessee was that the transaction in question involved nosale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer and as such, the amount in question was notcapital gain under section 12B of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distribution by liquidator recognizes pre-existing rights, not sale/exchange/transfer; supported by precedents and statutory interpretation.

arguments.claim: The surplus arose out of the exchange of shares held by the assessee company in the three companies and therefore the surplus ought to be brought to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner was of the view that the surplus arose out of the exchange of shares held by the assessee company in the three companies and therefore the surplus ought to be brought to tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: No sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer involved in liquidator's distribution.

arguments.claim: When a liquidator distributes the assets of a company which has gone into voluntary liquidation, he is performing a legal function and there is no element of sale, transfer, exchange or relinquishment involved in such distribution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court while answering the question in the negative held that when a liquidator distributes the assets of a company which has gone into voluntary liquidation, he is performing a legal function and there is noelement of sale, transfer, exchange or relinquishment involved in such distribution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mendment  Act wherein it was stated, inter alia, that any distribution of capital assets on the dissolution of a firm or other association of persons

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with reasoning on nature of liquidator's role.

arguments.claim: The transaction in question amounted to sale or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Manchanda on behalf of the appellant has argued in this Court that the transaction in question amounted to sale or transfer.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act of liquidator does not result in creation of new rights but recognition of existing ones; cites Buckley on liquidator as trustee.

arguments.claim: The omission of distribution on liquidation from the proviso in the revised section 12B shows that the legislature wanted such distributions to be treated as sale, exchange or transfer.
arguments.court_reasoning: Provisos allay fears without enlarging scope; plain words prevail over legislative history; cites Craies and Maxwell.

arguments.claim: Section 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 contains a provision for charging capital gains on liquidation distributions, implying similar treatment under 1922 Act.
arguments.court_reasoning: 1961 Act has express provision; 1922 Act lacks it and plain language does not cover.

arguments.claim: Liability to capital gains tax arises only from sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of capital asset after 31 March 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Perusal of sub-section (1) of section 12B reproduced above shows that the liability to pay tax on account of capital gains can arise only if the assessee makes profits or gains arising from the sale, exchange. relinquishment or transfer of a capital asset effected after March 31, 1956.

arguments.claim: Distribution by liquidator in voluntary liquidation does not result in creation of new rights but recognition of pre-existing legal rights of shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: The act of each of the liquidators in distributing the assets of the company which had gone into voluntary liquidation did not result in the creation of new rights. It merely entailed recognition of legal rights which were in existence prior to the distribution.

arguments.claim: Liquidator is a trustee who holds company property to apply as per statute, recognizing shareholder rights; no beneficial interest passes by transfer.

anchor.surface_text: According to observations on page 512 of Buckleys Commentaries on the Companies Act... a liquidator is only a trustee... When a shareholder receives money representing his share on distribution... he receives that money in satisfaction of the right which belonged to him... and not by operation of any transaction which amounts to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer.

arguments.claim: In Bankey Lal Vaidya, distribution on partnership dissolution is not sale/exchange/transfer.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income-tax U.P. v. Bankey Lal Vaidya... the arrangement between the partners... amounted to a distribution of the assets of the firm on dissolution and that there was no sale, exchange or transfer...

arguments.claim: James Anderson case distinguished: involved actual sale of assets, not distribution.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance... on behalf of the revenue upon the case of James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax. The said case was distinguished... in that case there was no distribution of capital assets between the legatees. On the contrary, the assessee had... sold the shares and securities...

arguments.claim: In Dewas Cine Corporation, adjustment of partner rights on dissolution by allotment is not sale or transfer for price.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation... the expression sale... is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm by allotment of its assets is not a transfer nor it is for a price.

arguments.claim: High Courts in Associated Industrial Development and R.M. Amin held liquidation distribution not assessable as capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Development Co. P. Ltd.... Similar view... by the Gujarat High Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin.

arguments.claim: Provisos are inserted to allay fears and guard against apprehended cases, not intended to apply; do not enlarge enactment scope.

anchor.surface_text: Provisos, as mentioned on page 221 of Craies on Statute Laws... are often inserted to allay fears. A proviso is inserted to guard against the particular case of which a particular person is apprehensive, although the enactment was never intended to apply to his case...

arguments.claim: Legislative history cannot override plain words of statute.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that considerations stemming from legislative history must not be allowed to override the plain words of a statute see Maxwell on the Interpretation of Statutes, Twelfth Edition, page 65.

arguments.claim: Proviso cannot enlarge scope or imply provisions into enacting part if plain and unambiguous.

holdings.text: distribution of the assets of the companies in liquidation does not amount to a transaction of sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer so as to attract section 12B of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that distribution of the assets of the companypanies in liquidation does number amount to a transaction of sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer so as to attract section 12B of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liquidator distributes recognizing pre-existing shareholder rights per company law (Buckley); analogous to partnership dissolution (Bankey Lal, Dewas); High Court precedents; plain words of s.12B(1) require sale/exchange/transfer.

holdings.text: the assessee company is [not] liable to pay tax on capital gains as contemplated by section 12B of the Act in respect of the amount of Rs. 95,944.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we find it difficult to hold that the assessee companypany is liable to pay tax on capital gains as companytemplated by section 12B of the Act in respect of the amount of Rs. 95,944.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sale/exchange/transfer/relinquishment in liquidation distribution; applies s.12B(1) strictly to facts.

holdings.text: the liability to pay tax on account of capital gains can arise only if the assessee makes profits or gains arising from the sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of a capital asset effected after March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Perusal of sub-section (1) of section 12B reproduced above shows that the liability to pay tax on account of capital gains can arise only if the assessee makes profits or gains arising from the sale, exchange. relinquishment or transfer of a capital asset effected after March 31, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of charging provision s.12B(1).

holdings.text: The act of each of the liquidators in distributing the assets of the company which had gone into voluntary liquidation did not result in the creation of new rights. It merely entailed recognition of legal rights which were in existence prior to the distribution.

anchor.surface_text: The act of each of the liquidators in distributing the assets of the companypany which had gone into voluntary liquidation did number result in the creation of new rights. It merely entailed recognition of legal rights which were in existence prior to the distribution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of liquidator's function under company law.

holdings.text: a liquidator is only a trustee in the sense that the property of the company ceases upon the winding up to belong beneficially to the company and passes into his custody, to be applied by him as directed by the statute... When a shareholder receives money representing his share on distribution... he receives that money in satisfaction of the right which belonged to him... and not by operation of any transaction which amounts to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Ac- companying to observations on page 512 of Buckleys Commentaries on the Companies Act, thirteenth edition, a liquidator is only a trustee in the sense that the property of the companypany ceases upon the winding up to belong beneficially to the companypany and passes into his custody, to be applied by him as directed by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Buckley on Companies Act; shareholder receives per existing rights, no new transaction.

holdings.text: the arrangement between the partners of the firm amounted to a distribution of the assets of the firm on dissolution and that there was no sale, exchange or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income-tax U.P. v. Bankey Lal Vaidya... the arrangement between the partners... amounted to a distribution of the assets of the firm on dissolution and that there was numbersale, exchange or transfer of the respondents share in the capital assets to D.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedent Bankey Lal Vaidya analogizing partnership dissolution to company liquidation.

holdings.text: James Anderson case... is not of such assistance to the revenue as in that case there was no distribution of capital assets between the legatees. On the contrary, the assessee had... sold the shares and securities.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance... on behalf of the revenue upon the ease of James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax. The said case was distinguished... in that case there was no distribution of capital assets between the legatees. On the contrary, the assessee had... sold the shares and securities...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes revenue precedent: involved actual sale, not distribution.

holdings.text: the expression sale... is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm by allotment of its assets is not a transfer nor it is for a price.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation... the expression sale... is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm by allotment of its assets is number a transfer number it is for a price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedent Dewas Cine on meaning of sale/transfer in dissolution context.

holdings.text: the amount received by a shareholder on the liquidation of a company was not assessable to capital gains as there was no sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of the capital assets.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Development Co. P. Ltd.... Similar view... by the Gujarat High Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows consistent High Court precedents directly on point.

holdings.text: Provisos... are often inserted to allay fears. A proviso is inserted to guard against the particular case of which a particular person is apprehensive, although the enactment was never intended to apply to his case.

anchor.surface_text: Provisos, as mentioned on page 221 of Craies on Statute Laws, Sixth Edition, are often inserted to allay fears. A proviso is inserted to guard against the particular case of which a particular person is apprehensive, although the enActment was never intended to apply to his case or to any other similar case at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies standard proviso interpretation (Craies); omission clarifies but doesn't expand s.12B(1).

holdings.text: considerations stemming from legislative history must not be allowed to override the plain words of a statute.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that companysiderations stemming from legislative history must number be allowed to override the plain words of a statute see Maxwell on the Interpretation of Statutes, Twelfth Edition, page 65.

holdings.text: A proviso cannot be construed as enlarging the scope of an enactment when it can be fairly and properly construed without attributing to it that effect... one cannot derive those provisions by implication from a proviso.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso limits to clarification, no enlargement (Craies).

holdings.text: section 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1961... contains a Provision for charging... on the liquidation of a company. The liability under that section arises from [its] express Provisions. It cannot... be said that such a liability would also arise even in the absence of such provisions under the Act of 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Reference has also been made by Mr. Manchanda to section 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 which companytains a Provision for charging with capital gains the money or assets received by a shareholder on the liquidation of a companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express provision in 1961 Act implies absence under 1922 Act; no harmonious implication.

anchor.surface_text: Re Windsor Steam Coal Co. 1 Semble, a liquidator is in the position of a trustee for the members when distributing surplus assets in specie in a winding up, so that numberbeneficial interest passes in the property conveyed or transferred, within the Finance 1909-1910 Act, 1910, s. 74 6

precedents.cited_proposition: a liquidator is in the position of a trustee for the members when distributing surplus assets in specie in a winding up, so that no beneficial interest passes in the property conveyed or transferred

precedents.cited_holding: the arrangement between the partners of the firm amounted to a distribution of the assets of the firm on dissolution and that there was no sale, exchange or transfer

precedents.citation: James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax. 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in that case was placed, as has been done also in the present case, on behalf of the revenue upon the ease of James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax. 1  The said case was distinguished and was found to be of number much avail to the revenue.

precedents.case_name: James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: sale of shares by power of attorney holder from executor resulted in capital gains taxable under section 12B

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation 2

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation 2  this Court while dealing with section 10  2  of the Act observed that the expression sale in its ordinary meaning is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm by allotment of its assets

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: sale means transfer of property for a price; allotment of partnership assets to partners on dissolution is not a sale or transfer for a price
precedents.cited_holding: property allotted to a partner in satisfaction of his claim to his share, could not be deemed in law to be sold to him

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Deve- lopment Co. P. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Deve- lopment Co. P. Ltd. 1  a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court held that the amount received by a shareholder on the liquidation of a company was not assessable to capital gains as there was no sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of the capital assets.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Associated Industrial Development Co. P. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: amount received by a shareholder on the liquidation of a company was not assessable to capital gains as there was no sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin . 2

anchor.surface_text: Similar view has also been taken by the Gujarat High Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin . 2 . We are, therefore, of the view that distribution of the assets of the companies in liquidation does not amount to a transaction of sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer so as to attract section 12B of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. R. M. Amin
precedents.cited_proposition: distribution of assets to shareholder on company liquidation does not amount to sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer taxable as capital gains

The concept of liability under Section 12B(1) grounds the argument stating the conditions for capital gains tax liability (sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer after 31 March 1956).
The holding that distribution does not amount to sale/exchange/etc. to attract Section 12B is grounded in the concept's definition of when liability arises.
The concept's conditions for liability address the core question of whether liquidation distribution triggers capital gains tax.
The proviso clarifies exclusions from section 12B, supporting the holding that liquidation asset distribution does not constitute a taxable transaction under section 12B.
The first proviso to section 12B(1), inserted to clarify exclusions, directly addresses the issue of whether liquidation distributions attract section 12B.
Sub-section (3) of section 12B addresses cost basis for assets acquired on liquidation, relevant to the issue of whether such distributions trigger section 12B.
